2011 Damon, batch 1! On tap at Hill Farmstead 7 year anniversary party. See these links for some serious cred:


http://i.imgur.com/q9ubRRF.jpeg 
http://i.imgur.com/wYt2IZ6.jpeg

Pours a viscous black with a tan head. Aroma of vanilla fudge, oak and a light bourbon. Tons of chocolate. Thick mouthfeel. Semi sweet. God nectar. Light barrel presence. Wow.

Bottle. Pours a pitch black beer with a very small ring of beige head on top. Aroma has lots of bourbon and chocolate, oak, molasses, touch of booze, syrup. Flavor is very sweet, lots of bourbon, lots of booze. Very sugary, nice aging going on. The flavor is full, darker chocolate and awesome in balance. Aftertaste is long and sweet. Great stuff.
500ml bottle @ Jamies. Pours a opaque black with a tiny tan head. Nose is very tasty, raisins, and chocolate. Flavour is molasses, raisins, hints of chocolate and quite sweet.

Brown bottle, 500 ml, bottled on 04.13.16, savoured on August 6 2016; eye: black, opaque, ring of beige head, light lacing; nose: roasted malt, bourbon, molasses, anise, slight alcohol, slight coffee, slight chocolate; mouth: roasted malt, bourbon, molasses, anise, slight alcohol, slight coffee, slight chocolate, light alcohol warmth, finale in bourbon with good presence of roasted barley, full body, below-average carbonation, mildly sweet, silky texture; overall: quite good

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 500 ml, embouteillée le 04.13.16, savourée le 6 août 2016; il : noire, opaque, anneau de mousse brune, légère dentelle; nez : malt torréfié, bourbon, mélasse, anis, très léger alcool, très léger café, très léger chocolat; bouche : malt torréfié, bourbon, mélasse, anis, très léger alcool, très léger café, très léger chocolat, léger chaleur dalcool, finale en bourbon avec bonne présence dorge torréfiée, corsée, carbonatation sous la moyenne, moyennement sucrée, texture soyeuse en résumé : bien bon

750ml bottle shared by Theydon_Bois @Ma che siete venuti a fà (thanks Colin!). Nera, densa, impenetrabile, bella schiuma color cappuccino, molto persistente. Naso pulito ed elegante, di enorme raffinatezza, sentori di malti tostati, cioccolato fondente, leggera vaniglia, alcol nascosto. In bocca è vellutata e setosa al palato, morbida ed equilibrata ma al tempo stesso intensa, lunga, complessa e appagante. Note di cioccolata fondente, melassa, note legnose, finale amarognolo appena caffettoso, alcol non pervenuto. Imperial Stout sopraffina, di classe straordinaria.

Pours an oily black color with a small, dark brown head, which vanishes immediately.

The aromas of this are simply amazing - theres a lot going on with licorice, scorched malts, tobacco and dark chocolate. The barrel adds a tremendous depth with dried apples, rock sugar, peppers, dried plum and lots of spicy wood, tickling the nose by developing a boozy warmth.

Drinks silk and velvet, full bodied with lots and lots of alcohol soaked layers of rich maltiness. 

Tastes right from the beginning of burned malts, wild honey, whipped cream as for its awesome mouthfeel, and fudge. Develops a spicy licorice roastiness once the barrel gets noteable, together with cinnamon, toasted nuts and a luscious amount of bitter chocolate. Finishes with molasses, melting chocolate, long lasting tobacco, dried earth and a flowery note from the otherwise still pleasantly spicy barrel.

This is like an amped up Bourbon County - not necessarily thicker on the tongue, but even creamier with more roast and bitter chocolate, countered by an even sweeter fudge note, balanced by earth and spices. Awesomly intense and balanced throughout.
Pitch black pour, offwhite head. Amazing aroma, bourbon , dried dark fruit, coffee, roasted malt. Black chocolate giving way to bourbon, coffee, blueberry, dark malt. Fuller body. Amazing.
Very imperial stout aroma. Bourbon character in finish. Very opaque brown. Some head. Very smooth. Pretty good, like nitro.

500ml bottle, 2016, deep abyssal black color, with a tan-coloured head, with a nice fruity dark chocolate, mild bourbonish nose, with some vanilla oak barrel, toffee, light chocolate cup filled with bourbon liqueur, brownie, sweet roasted, chocolate, black, toast malty accents, and some burnt fruitcake, cocoa, mocha coffee notes in the aroma follows through on a full-bodied palate with a warmth good syrupy chocolatey, molasses, fruity bourbon barrel, vanilla, burnt fruitcake character, with some sweet roasted, chocolate, black, wheat, toasted malty, brownie, dark chocolate baking bar, burnt chocolate cake, chocolate syrup flavours, leading towards a warming syrupy chocolatey bourbonish, a lingering sweet fruity roasted, chocolate, toasted, wheat maltiness finish.

Bottle, shared by a (crazy generous) friend from high school. Everything about the initial appearance of this beer is impressive. Its jet-black with a mocha-white head, and it pours into the glass like a viscous oil. The aroma is moderate bourbon and sweet chocolate. The taste leans more towards the traditional Russian Imperial Stouts Ive had, with more sweetness and dark fruit than chocolate or coffee, and the bourbon barrel flavor is reasonably restrained, giving some undertones and aroma, but mostly allowing the malt to take center stage.
Bottle. Black black black. Aroma is chocolate, cocoa, very fudgy and a little bready. Taste is sweet, coffee and chocolate, rich and thick, chewy, gorgeous. Wow.

Bottled April 13, 2015, drunk 10/21/16, thanks to Blisscent.The usual perfect pour from a bottled HF product. Dark ebony-cocoa body of undetermined clarity. Large, dense head, strong retention, etc....Right away the first thing I notice is that its significantly less boozy than the port barrel version, which is odd since this is much younger than when I had the port. Anyways, bourbon character is moderate, definitely a big portion of the nose, but not dominant and its backed by cocoa, prunes, fudge and very even, mild roast. Vanilla, graham cracker and caramel on the finish, show the malt depth and the bourbon dries out the finish, with spicy liquor notes and light wood. Low on the alcohol, with just a hint of warmth and no flaws.Rich, of course, in the mouth with plentiful bourbon notes backed by rich fudgey malts. Cocoa, cola, cherry, vanilla and caramel all present a fairly straightforward Imperial as the chalky, mineral-rich water of HF works its magic on the less tangible character of the beer. Velvety, but not syrupy, malty but not cloying, with tight carbonation and very light alcohol warmth. Delightful. Thanks, Nelson.

Thanks Adamchandler. What a gem. Both him and the beer ;). Anyway, this rocks. Pours thick and black with faint dark head that immediately disappears. Aromas of fresh dough, molasses, anise. Notes of espresso. Flavours of bourbon, sherry, coconut, nuts, anise, molasses, bitter chocolate. So smooth and drinkable. Phenomenal.

Bottle shared with koleminer20, Chris, and Doug for the Lions share. Aroma is chocolate, roasted malt, bourbon, barrel, coffee, robust. Appearance is black, brown head, poured thick. Taste is roasted malt, licorice, chocolate, bourbon, barrel, complex and great. Mouthfeel is heavy body, light carbonation, chocolate and barrel aftertaste. Overall, really really good.

500ml bottle. Black pour with red hues and a foamy mahogany head. Flavors are lightly roasted cereals, fudge, milk chocolate, molasses, toffee, vanilla, bourbon and alcohol with resinous and fruity notes. Full body, soft to moderate carbonation, oily texture.

From notes. Enjoyed this during the 2nd Annual Kellys Island Bottle Share on September 18. 500 mL bottle. Ive been excited about this for a while. The pour is a thinner black with a light brown head that falls slowly to a collar leaving a couple spots of lace. The aroma has a lot of barrel and bourbon on it. There is a good sweet molasses and a nice dark chocolate. A hint of vanilla pokes in and does well. The flavor is better. There is a light bourbon and molasses at the front end. A good charred oak and dark chocolate vanilla combo roll in slowly, and there is a dark fruit on the finish. Its really complex, but its missing that wow factor. The mouth feel is a little thin and light. There is a nice soft carbonation and a lingeringly sweet molasses and chocolate to go with a hint of bourbon and a light vanilla on the finish. Excellent stout.

My Bottom Line:
This luxurious Barrel-Aged Imperial Stout lays rich bourbon vanilla atop dark fruit jam, burnt caramel and bitter roastiness, in a most velvety mouthfeel.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A slice of foam tops the impenetrable black.
-Molasses is also found in the flavour profile.
-There is a lot going on here, but every flavour works in the same direction.
-The roasty bitterness balances the heavy sugars perfectly.
-You obviously need to be in the mood for dessert for this one. But when you are, oh my
-Smoked blue cheese was perfect for this one.

Bottle.

500ml bottle dated 04/13/16 shared with my wife. Pours dark chocolate brown with a caramel brown head. Aroma is dark chocolate, raisin, toffee, coffee, vanilla, bourbon, oak. Smells delicious! Flavor is dark chocolate, raisin, licorice, vanilla, bourbon, oak. Smooth. Great brew!

Poured from a 04/13/2016 bottle. 
Aroma is fairly malt forward with a lot of balanced dark chocolate and roast notes. Some faint caramel and toffee notes. Medium bourbon notes with some lighter oak and alcohol spice. Hints of dark fruit and raisins. Some light tobacco and ash notes. 
Pours black with thick, dark mocha head that steadily recedes to the edges then lingers. No lacing and moderate legs. 
Flavor is fairly sweet with lots of roast and chocolate malt notes. Light tobacco and ash notes. Medium bourbon notes with some light oak character. Low bitterness and light alcohol spice. Lingering dark chocolate notes with a touch of milk chocolate. 
Mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with medium low carbonation; a bit of creaminess. Low astringency and medium low alcohol warmth. 
Overall, a pretty nice stout. I think I like this more than the port barrel one. Nice chocolate flavors with great malt complexity. Balanced roast with hints of tobacco and ash.

Apparence : Noire opaque, coule visqueuse, anneau brun foncé, carbonatation très faible. 
Nez : Mélasse, réglisse ooire, effluves de vanille, de chocolat noir, de bois et dalcool fort. 
Goût : Mélasse et réglisse noire en entrée, suivies de notes torréfiées pour finir sur des notes de bois alcoolisé et, en moindre mesures, de chocolat noir. Légère amertume, assez sucrée. 
Sensation : Effervescence quasi absente, pleine, picotement éthylique sur la langue, chaleur élevée en gorge, bonne longueur. 
Bref : Une bière qui, à mon goût, est axée sur les saveurs de mélasse tout de même sucrée avec du chocolat et le fut pour équilibrer ce qui aurait été bière débalancée et beaucoup trop sucrée à mon avis. Très bonne intensité et plaisir à la boire. 
Je dois par contre avouer être quelque peu dubitatif de la réputation dont cette bière jouit. Je crois que celle-ci est due en bonne partie à la bière elle-même (elle est excellente, nen doutons pas), en partie au nom de la brasserie et une autre petite partie à la rareté de la bouteille. De plus, mes impressions des saveurs dune bière rejoignent habituellement ce que la majorité des gens en disent, mais ici, jai eu droit à un profil auquel je ne mattendais pas (beaucoup de mélasse). Excellente, mais peut-être pas de classe mondiale à mon humble avis!

500 ml bottle at home.. celebrating the #IPAday! Pitch black color with nice brown head. Aroma is malty, roasted, chocolate, dark chocolate, light cocoa, some light coffee notes too, dark dried fruits, figs, raisins, plums, some red fruits, coconut, vanilla, wood, light alcohol. Heavy sweet and light bitter taste like aroma but even better. Full silky oily to creamy body with soft carbonation. I need more bottles!!

500ml bottle from trade Dominic shared with Guillaume. Aroma: strong bourbon, chocolate, slightly smoked and licorice. App: dark brown, really minimal brown head. Taste and palate: medium to full body, creamy, velvety, medium sweetness, really subtle bitter finish.overall: damn good. This is complex. The kind of beer that gives you goose bumps. Really good! Glad I had the pleasure to taste this one.

Bottle. Vintage 2013 from Tommy, thanks man! Beautiful appearance; thick black with chocolate milk head and nice lacing. Aroma is ash, oak, vanilla, chocolate, and spirits. Taste is chocolate fudge, ash, oak, and vanilla. Finishes with a bitter coffee like aftertaste and a slight hint of booze. Pretty damn awesome to say the least, wishfull thinking thatll ever try this again so I am going to savour every last sip.

November 14, 2015. Bottle at home, vintage 2011. Received in a trade with heyta, thanks!  Black with a small dense, quickly dissipating, brown head. Aroma is sweet with bourbon, caramel, figs, blackberries, wood, dark chocolate, coffee and some spicy notes. Taste is sweet malty with a light bitterness and hints of bourbon alcohol. Finish is sweet and soft light bitterness with figs, dark sugar, dark berries, vanilla, dark chocloate, coffee and some hints of black pepper and dried chili, light alcohol notes. Full bodied, soft carbonation, creamy mouthfeel. 
Great complex, imperial stout with a nice balanced bourbon character.

Huge thanks to sideshowe for sharing. Bottle 281. 

Pours a dark chestnut brown color that appears black and opaque in the glass. Half finger dark mocha head that quickly settles into a lasting ring leaving spotty lacing behind.

Smokey, roasted malt aroma with subtle barrel integration. Some toasted oak and subtle booziness with more of an oak and peaty scotch presence than sweet, boozy bourbon. There a faint malt backbone with some smoke, dark chocolate, coffee bean and oatmeal but the oak and peat notes overpower things a bit. 

Medium bodied with a nice smokey barrel presence thats nicely integrated into the dark malts of the base beer. Smokey, peaty scotch flavor with toasted oak, ash, smoked meat and burnt malt along with subtle vanilla and dry oak. This is countered by a balance of sweet and roasted dark malt flavors with hints of dark chocolate, toast, coffee bean and oatmeal. Well balanced with a nicely integrated barrel presence, however, Im getting more of a dry oak than bourbon flavor. Complex with a well masked ABV that makes it easy to drink but theres something a touch off that i cant put mu finger on. Still, an enjoyable beer that Im glad to have tried.

Bottled. A black beer with a rim of brown head - sirupy thick. The aroma has notes of roasted malt, alcohol, soy sauce, and wood. The flavor is sweet with notes of roasted malt, soy sauce, chocolate, vanilla, alcohol, and vanilla, leading to a bitter finish.
500 ml. shared bottle. Pours black with a decent tan head. Aroma of bourbon, malt, chocolate, and vanilla. Taste is bourbon, roasted malt, dark chocolate, dark fruit, vanilla, and wood. More please!

500 mL bottle poured into a snifter. Bottle # 723/864. Originally reviewed
10/29/2012. Small khaki head. Not quite inky. Wispy lacing.

Smells of tons of black patent malt. Light bourbon. A big oaky presence, more than the bourbon and vanilla.
Lots more barrel blends into the flavor. Bourbon is still light, but vanilla and caramel come out. Dark fruit flavor right at the front, which might be a byproduct of the alcohol and black patent malt. Lots of molasses. Gives it a bitter flavor in the back. Bitter. Not really chewy, but easy to drink at this ABV. The molasses gives it a sweet flavor that implies viscosity, without it actually being there.

Second time having this it was significantly better than the first. I was also smashed the first time. It would be really good with more barrel presence.
A special occasion needs a special brew. Lovely at both smell and taste, one of the best in a while.

Une bière noire à la mousse couleur café et onctueuse. Je dois de prime abord mentionner que Shaun ma véritablement impressionné avec cette Impériale Stout; ce type de bière nétant pas la spécialité de la Maison, jai été cette fois sidéré! Nez dune complexité remarquable de malts fumés, de mélasse, de toffee, de caramel, danis et de bourbon. Cest à sy perdre tellement cest beau et équilibré! Les saveurs de vanille, de fruits confits et en général de gâteau aux fruits au Cognac. Prodigieuse concoction, à la fois riche, savoureuse et légère dune des plus belles brasseries de ce monde!

Pours dark with a fine brown head that dissipates to end up hugging my glass. The aroma is of sweet bourbon, oak, chocolate, sweet malts, booze, some vanilla, and a mild fruit character. As I taste this I pick up on a full and rich body. I noticed bourbon, roasted malts, vanilla, buttery caramelized candy syrup, cocoa, and dark fruit. The finish was rather nice and it was kind to my palate. Overall this beverage very enjoyable and is worth obtaining. Share with a good friend.

Thickest black with little glint of viscosity and a thick oily battery rust orange lacing. Decadent coconut, wheatsheaf and kola cube bourbon sweetness. Lean liquorice roast throughout and softly sweet initial taste. Dank steamy choc, dark without being full clown cocoa bitterness. Neat bitterness in the back end. Smooth and creamy without being overly cloying and a nice aniseedy bitter pinch on the lift. Finish is not dissimilar, evenly paced and a linger of liquorice and roast blackcurrants. It looks the part and walks the walk, with a nice wee nudge of boozey bitterness on the fade but is subdued and more ashen than Id hoped. BenHs 
car tasting, thanks to the Birmingham stars aligning.

Thanks to the legends that allowed this to happen. Black with tan head. Thick aroma, molasses, wood, chocolate. Taste of salty licorice, molasses, chocolate, oak. Super sweet with a little heat. Delish

Bottle at brum tasting.. Deep black... Thin tan lacing... Dark heavy roast.. Big bourbon.. Light coconut nose.. Dark roast malts... Dark roast... Long dry chocolate bitter.. Big chocolate big malts... Somedark roast suger... Soft meaty malt.. Heavy roast
Bottle. Pours black tan head. Nose/taste of bourbon, fudge nut brownie, oak and roast chocolate. Full body.
Bottle. Black pour with brown head. Dark malt, maybe sweet aromas. Very Scandinavian, dark, roasted and flavorful.
Bottle - Roasty malts and nice bourbon notes. Jet black with a decent light brown head. Light chocolate, bourbon notes, vanilla and no heat. Very well balanced and superb.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2015 Pours black , no real head . Smell is bit bitter, roasted malts . Taste is chocolatty , bitter , dark malts . Creamy, full mouthfeel . perfect mouthfeel . Pretty damn nice ! 

re-rate. Bottle at the Ultimate Imperial Stout Tasting. Thnx for the awesome day, folks! This bottle was shared by Dennoman. Thought bourbon was a seperate beer, but it seems that this was the basic beer. This specific bottle tasted a bit sharper, and I scored it 4,1 instead of the earlier 4,4. So updating it to 4,2.

Bottle poured into snifter. Appears black, fairly opaque with a small mocha head that breaks into some spotty lacing. Hints of some legs up the glass, but they are short lived. Aromas of wet oak, chocolate, dark fruits, molasses and anise. Taste is subdued, but the character is nicely balanced. Oak and molasses harmonize but was hoping for a bit more substance out of the body. A little light on the palate but provides some nice depth with roasted nuttiness permeating through in the finish along with a warming bourbon. Nice offering!

Bottle poured in a snifter. Deep brown-black, not too thick-looking. Very thin, cinnamon-colored head. Sweet and nutty aroma. Pecans, almonds, maple, vanilla extract, tangy chocolate. Rich. Very oaky flavor. Chocolate syrup, butterscotch, vanilla and maple in the front. The swallow brings alcohol, graham crackers and burnt toast. Sweet throughout, smooth. Can easily see myself downing a whole bottle in minutes. Body is just a touch thin -- medium-light. Carbonation is nearly not there, just a gentle tingle. Hardly any alcohol burn except a flash at the swallow. A perfect blend of flavors, enjoyable and crazy drinkable. A beautiful beer. Just need a bit more body and co2.

Bottle at Anchorage Dec 14 Tasting: Poured a brown black with a light brown head. Aroma was boozy fermented dark fruit, chocolate, bourbon, and mixture of malt character. Taste was licorice, bourbon, boozy alcohol, caramel/toffee malt.

Bottle, batch 2. Pours deep black with brown head. Verey well integrated bourbon, dark chocolate, smoke. Taste is litterally liquid chocolate soaked in bourbon, coffee bitterness. Rich and liquorous. A masterpiece.

2011 vintage.
Pours pitch black, with a small khaki head that turns into a ring that sticks to the glass. Real oily up is in this bitch. 
Aroma is big of bourbon, slight toasted coconut, plenty of vanilla, banana, caramel, big fudge, slight smoke, dark fruits soaked in booze, licorice, some booze. 
Taste is pretty sweet, with some roasted bitterness to it. Medium n oily body, with a flat carbonation. Pretty darn complex, and darn delicious. Thanks a big bunch to mr. Booggy for sending this my way.

Bottle @ home Trade from Pandableh...500ml bottle vintage 2013.. It pours dark almost black with a medium tan head....Dark chocolate, bourbon, coconut, vanilla, dark fruit, coffee..... near perfect! Thanks for this fine brew! love it!

Yes, this is inky, strong and unstoppably opaque. A milky film of sea foam lies gently atop the murkiness, weakly hiding its myriad secrets. Roasted, bitter and sweet nutty accents come in and out at various moments. Strong and dark notes. The alcohol is kept under control-- impressive, considering its generous role. Damon would be proud to have this fine libation concocted in his magnificent honor.

Shared by Taylor M. Thanks man. Inky black pour with a dense chestnut brown head. Nose is very rich and layered, Bourbon/wood with burnt sugar and molasses following. Dark fruit and nuanced dark chocolate. Full and weighty in the mouth, coating and viscous finish. Vanilla and burnt wood in the flavor with blackstrap and dark fruit skins. Lovely.

batch 2 bottle thank to matt! shared it with a friend. poured a dark black colour with just a slight mocha coloured head. nice lacing. incredible complex aroma. sweet bakers chocolate, molasses, caramel, bourbon, oak, dark roast. the taste is really complex. the sweet chocolate and bourbon flavours are just together as one! some vanilla, toffee. smooth and creamy mouthfeel. amazing

Dark brown/black, viscous, golden brown head. Aroma is bourbon, molasses, dark fruits, booze, hint of coffee. Full bodied, oily mouthfeel, rich and smooth on the palate with a long sweet finish. Taste is bourbon, chocolate, golden syrup, maple syrup, wood, coffee, dark fruits.

Bouteille 08-2013. Belle robe noire. La texture semble visqueuse. Un premier nez boisé avec des notes de whiskey. Une bouche chaude, puissante, très puissante. Des saveurs classiques de Impy au bourbon. Bien faite.

Damon dans le vintage 2013. Brun très foncé avec un anneau plutôt chétif. Au nez, décadence à la romaine avec du chocolat qui fume, du bourbon caramélisé, du café riche, du bois rôti et des touches de mélasse de figues et/ou de dattes. Au goût, des fruits foncés et du chocolat en abondance, des notes douces, vanillées et caramélisés, un bourbon intégré et/ou évaporé, un mince effet poivré et des friandises anglaises très sucrées et caloriques qui rendent lappareil un peu lourd et collant. En bouche, un corps balourd qui reste attaché aux commissures de mes lèvres. En finale, une bombe chocolatée, caramélisée et vanillée qui explose sur les malts rôtis et torréfiés. Beau nez et bouche beaucoup (voire même excessivement) trop sucrée. Glucides simples, obésité, diabète, maladies cardio-vasculaires sont des mots qui me viennent soudainement à lesprit. Dans lensemble, cest correct et délicieux mais, pour moi, ça reste loin du spectacle et de lincroyable.

Bottle: Black, inky center with lush mahogany edges. A fine, mocha film slowly forms up top, then disperses quickly towards the edges. Wow, lovely aroma of rich, dark fudge, chocolate cake batter, sweet bakers cocoa, smooth whiskey, mild tannic oak, vanilla, burnt toffee, & just a touch of powdered coffee. Very robust, yet delicate & pedantic all at once. The flavor is excellent, & has a nice German Chocolate Cake vibe to it; dense chocolate mixing with a hint of coconut & vanillin from the barrel. Woody & slightly tannic mid-palate, but not overdone. Smooth bourbon lathered throughout. A hint of char towards the finish, as a big, burnt brown sugar profile comes swooping in, leaving your palate with an intrinsic sweetness in the aftertaste. Nice, creamy mouth feel. A pretty fantastic stout. Blows out the Port barrel aged version by a nautical mile.

Served alongside Port Damon and Double Barrel Damon.

The beer is dark brown, near black, with a small beige collar. Aromas of dark roast, chocolate. Rich and flavorful. Dark chocolates. Oak and bourbon character are there, but dont overwhelm the flavor profile. Elegant feel. Medium to full bodied with moderate carbonation. While I enjoy everything Hill Farmstead, in general, it seems the stouts are not quite up to the level of their saisons and IPAs.

500 ml bottle is 2013 vintage. Pours a near black with maroon hues on the edge with a lasting beige edge head. Aroma is roast, smoke, raisins, chocolate malt, and a slight bourbon spiciness. Flavor is same, with moderate carbonation. Full syrupy mouthfeel.

500ml bottle pours dark rich brown black with a finger of tan head. Nose is so deep you could fall into it...dark bourbon chocolate, cake, coconut, vanilla, subtle dark fruit, roasty cocoa, coffee. Taste is more of the same rich roasty bitter cocoa, chocolate sauce, cake, vanilla coffee, balanced bourbon. Finis has lingering boozy cocoa and coffee with coconut, vanilla, bourbon fruit spice, and roasty chocolate. Mouthfeel is creamy silk. Just great.

Poured from bottle into tulip: Pours black with a nice tan head. Aroma of vanilla, bourbon, dark fruits, chocolate, coffee. Taste is more of the same but also a little earthy. A little sweet as to be expected with an Imperial Stout, but not overwhelming. The sweetness is knocked down with the coffee flavor on the back end. Medium carbonation, full body, silky mouthfeel, this is a wonderful stout.

Aug 2013 bottle thanks to the local group for sharing. Black pour with a thin, tan head that fades to a thin ring. Aromas are tobacco, coffee, vanilla, and bourbon. Taste is more complex than the aroma. Sweet chocolate syrup, vanilla, coffee, caramel, anise, dark fruit tobacco, and strong bourbon. The bourbon is pretty powerful in this but no heat at all. Medium body. Smooth and a little creamy.

Bottle: The aroma consists of milk chocolate, vanilla, light molasses, caramel, bourbon, a hint of apple, and anise. It pours a dark brown with no transparency with a small tan head that quickly fades to a very fine ring. The flavor starts with moderate-heavy milk chocolate, molasses, caramel, and faint fruit. The finish has light espresso, bourbon, anise, and a touch of oak. Its medium-full bodied with mild carbonation and a creamy mouthfeel.

(500ml bottle) jet black, creamy dark tan head, excellent glass coating. Nose of bourbon, french oak, light ash, alcoholic, maple. Taste is ashy, alcohol, burnt sugars, light bourbon, a bit unbalanced and estery, tons of wood in the finish.
Batch 2. Black pour, tan head. Nose is very light barrel, some chocolate, some dark fruits. Taste is the same, hard to distinguish the barrel at times. Meduim mouthfeel.

beige head that disappears quickly but not entirely with some lacing. coffee coloured. pours viscous, thick like motor oil. taste is boozy, solvent, vanilla, caramal, soy, hazlenut. taste is like aroma, coconut, coffee, umami. mouthfeel is very slick, almost velvet. very dense body, almost no carbonation. woah, this is stellar, so complex and intense!  bottle 50cl / bd feb-13
Thanks berntholer, for sharing this one. If you would like to smell & taste chocolate, praline, hazelnut, soja, vanille, coffee, this is your beer. Velvet mouthfeel. Long aftertaste. Excellent brew!

UPDATED: MAY 4, 2015 Bottles kindly shared by Tom 10101 & JHuxley during our epic CMLSG cellar tasting - all 3 versions put next to each other. All of them have an incredibly nice balance between sweetness and roastiness which is unparallelled vs. other American BA RISs, which make them all great beers.
- Damon: 3.9/5: subtle vanilla and cocoa in the aromas
- Damon PBA;: 4.2/5: my favourite: more depth and complexity. Nose reveils cigars, leather, red fruits. Taste is roasty with a nice vinious touch of raisins. 
- Damon DBA 4/5: despite the fact that it is the most balanced in the nose, I think the taste is a tad bland.
------
Re-t all of them at The Ultimate Imperial Stout Tasting April 2015. Keeping scores for the PBA & BBA The DBA has aged wonderfully and is thé best Acan Stout to date for me: balanced, subtle and extremely tasteful. Upped the DBA to 4.7.

Bottle as shown thanks to Matt. Pours a very dark brown with medium tan head that lasts awhile. The aroma is strong roast, faint metallic, and chocolate. Medium mouthfeel with strong roast, dark chocolate, sweet malt, and light bitterness. Easy to drink, very good.

Bouteille 500 mL. Noire opaque, mousse légère brunâtre. Nez de torréfaction et de bourbon. Bouche au corps dense, épaisse quasi-sirupeuse: toasts, fumée et barrique de bourbon (bourbon, vanille et chêne). Pas aussi intense quimaginé, ce qui est une qualité.
all the fuss over Damon, now i get what the big deal is. it really is pretty amazing.

Bottle, graciously shared by AdamJackson - thanks! Pours inky black with a nice medium brown head, creamy and slow to dissipate, leaving nice lacing in its wake. Aroma is roasty, dark chocolate, notes of bourbon. Flavor follows, deeply roasty, but not burned, dark baking chocolate. Medium sweet, but well balanced by medium bitterness. Bourbon is present, but not dominant, as well as some vanilla and oak tannins. Full body, super soft and creamy mouthfeel - beers like this make me wish there was a "6" rating for palate. ABV well masked. Nice beer.

Bottle shared at Ma Che, thanks to Frank from PA for the trade, 08/02/14.
Pitch black with a dirty tan swirl and edgework atop the glass.
Nose is roast malt, light booze, dark toffee fudge, good bourbon twang, dark berry fruits, oaky bourbonics, rich dark chocolate.
Taste comprises luxurious chocolate, well integrated bourbon, light coffee notes, molasses, dark berry fruits, brown sugars, raisens, touch of booze.
Medium bodied, soft carbonation, smooth on the palate, great feel.
Excellent impy, the alcohol is well integrated and never harsh.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text:
**First and foremost, my scores reflect the times I have had this beer on-tap at the brewery events while the words reflect the bottled version.**


Thanks to DocJ007 for sharing this one with us last weekend, Batch #2.


A - Pours jet black with a small half finger tall tan head, quickly dissipating down to a light ring around the edge of the glass, leaving little to no lace at all on the glass.


S - Smells of warm bourbon, fudgey chocolate, vanilla, molasses, dark fruits, overly charred oak and plenty of dark roasted malt. Lots of dark aromas lurking in the shadows of this one.


T - Starts off much like the nose does with a bit sugary kick - mainly the fudgey chocolate, vanilla, molasses mixed dark fruits - quickly being joined by the smokey charred oak and base dark roasted malts. Finish is much like before with a mix of sweetness and dark roasty flavors, lingering long after the finish.


M - Heavy body with moderate to low carbonation. Slick feel throughout, booze is hidden quite well.


O - I enjoyed this one quite a bit. Not as good as when I had it on-tap but still a very enjoyable beer. Really looking forward to trying that Double Barrel version in the near future.

500ml bottle. Huge thanks to Dany. Aroma is sweet bourbon. Very subtitle. Taste is bourbon, smoke, oak, cane sugar. Everything is blended very well, not an extreme beer but very well balanced. Good stuff but not worth the crazy hype.

2011 vintage shared at Perennial. Original review 06-26-12.

Pours black, mocha-colored head, wisps, thin collar. This is a Blantons/bourbon bomb straight away! After the huge booze, theres roasted malts, chocolate, light bread, caramel, oak, very subtle hops, and burnt sugars. The booze flairs my nostrils...woah. I think this beer needs to additional cellar time to lose some of the booze. The palate offers lots of bourbon, oak, chocolate, light vanilla, caramel, and toasted malts. The alcohol is very noticeable, which detracts from the rest of the beer. Finish is chocolate and booze with light oak. Medium to full body, good carbonation, rich, creamy finish.

While I like this beer, I want to like it more. I think another 6 months to a year of additional cellar time will do this beer some good. I will revisit then and update when I have it again. Right now, I suggest holding your bottles unless you really want a bunch of alcohol with your RIS (which some people prefer). In summary, good now but is destined to be great in the future.

Another gem shared at Atl Fantasy Football Meetup. Deep black pour with perhaps the slighted amount of carbonation. This was a minor takeaway. Aroma is big chocolate and rich sweet bourbon and perhaps some oak. Taste was rich cocoa nibs, vanilla, a bit boozy, oak, more chocolate. Not going let the hype train persude. While a very good brew, not amogst the best. Stilll delighted to try as much as I can from HFS.

This one poured a very dark brown to black color with a burnt brown sugar colored head. Aroma was lots of bourbon, brown sugar, mild smoke and dried fruits too. Flavor was similar, more roasted and smokey than I was expecting, not much residual sugar either, but loads of spirit.

Bottle at FoCo Stout Tasting 2013, courtesy of Aaron. Big thanks for the pour man! Pour is pitch black with a creamy brown head and good lacing. Big bourbon, coconut, dark chocolate, coffee, earthy, and toffee aroma. Taste is big dark chocolate, vanilla, coffee, bourbon, toffee, caramel, leathery and tangy with a long roasted chocolate finish. Slick mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Really nice stuff.

Bottle @ Armins place, courtesy of Lukaduke. Big thanks! Pours a deep brown appearance with a dark brown head. Somewhat floral, dark chocolate, light caramel, cereal, a bit grainy, well balanced aroma. Dark grape, plum, a touch boozy, rich chocolate, light whiskey, slight woody flavor. Pretty fucken tasty beer but not quite as good as I thought it may be.
Pour thanks to adnielsen. Aroma is vanilla and dark fruits. Flavor is the same with some bitter dark chocolate on the finish. Dope

Pour out of 500 mL bottle, thanks Aaron! Dark black pour with off white head, aroma brought notes of dark chocolate, roast, hints of coffee, nice oak, bourbon, this is delicious. Taste is a mix of dark cocoa, bourbon, oak, slight vanilla, honey, finishing slight dry, sweet. This is delicious.
UPDATED: NOV 24, 2013 Bottle thanks to cpetrone84. Pours jet black with a brown head. Light bourbon aroma. Not much heat. Medium light carb and medium thick body.
no bullshit inane bloviation could add anything else to the discussion of descriptions of this beer.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2015 Dune richesse biblique avec tous les attributs dont je souhaitais retrouver, cuir, tabac, charbon, fudge, cerises, caramel, vanille, coco dans une onctuosité qui me placarde le palais sans pitié. Meilleure que la version en fût dégusté au 2e anniversaire....à moins que ce soit les circonstances de la dernière dégustation qui prennent le dessus sur mon jugement?

Black colour, tan head. Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, roasted malts, soy sauce, wood, red fruits and marzipan. Quite sweet flavour, bourbon, vanilla, malts, caramel and soy sauce. Quite thick body. Finish caramel, bourbon, wood and cacao. Great beer.
(From 66cL bottle shared by joes @ his place. Thanks!!!)

Bottle: Served in a taster:
Motoroil black pour.
Medium to smaller sized brown foamy head on top of a black colored beer with a dark red brown edge.
Aromas of bourbon, flowers, vanilla, wood, creamy liquorice, roast, marzepin, some malt roast, delicious aroma.
Flavours of roast, bitters, light spicy, wood, cream, vanilla, some liquorice, chocolate, light liquor, marzepin, some bourbon. Very nice.
Aftertaste is a mix of bitters, roast, chocolate, some bourbon, cream, 
Low carbo, silky mouthfeel, full body and a creamy oily sticky texture.
Some alcohol/warmth bit balanced, smooth and delicious.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Bottle shared by Joes @ weekly tasting. Opaque pitch black color, small instantly disappearing light brown head. Aroma is wood, bourbon, some liquorice, malts and roasted malts. Taste malts, liquorice, wood, a hint of coffee-bitter, bourbon and bitter. Full body, medium carbonation. Nice long lingering finish. Nice!

Bottle @ joes thx to joes. Pitch black colour with a small but lovely dark brown head. Smells bourbon, hazelnut, sweet, alcohol, cork, oak, whisky. Tastes sweet, oak, some bourbon, some whisky, chocolate, roasty, red wine. Quite nice, but slightly alcoholic. Full body, silky, soft carbo.

Bottle shared thanks to another group at Local Option, Chicago. Pours near black with a small brown head. Aroma of dark chocolate, roast, bourbon, vanilla, coffee, molasses, toffee licorice and some dark overripe fruit. Flavour is light heavy sweet and bitter. Full bodied with soft carbonation. Really good!

Bottle courtesy of some random fellow beer geeks in Local Option, Chicago. Thanks! Poured a deep mahogany with a rich oily consistency. The aroma is rich liqourice bitter with lots of roasted malt and alcohol. The flavour is strong bitter with a rich roasted malt liqourice alcohol raisin fruit palate. A real whale.

Bottle with a date of 08-2013. Used motor oil color with little wisps of tan head. The brew actually looks like an oil spill in the snifter. Translucent sheen on the top of the stout. Aroma starts with bourbon, oak and vanilla, chocolate and rich deep roasted malts. Damn, the flavor is like drinking a chocolate cake soaked in smooth bourbon. Chocolate cake batter upfront, anise and light hints of coffee all the while a nice smooth bourbon nuance in the finish. The texture is slick and oily which is consistent with the motor oil look in the glass. Leaves a slick, sticky feel on the tongue. Slight warming sensation after the sip, yet no intense burn, real mild. If Mr. Hill release this again next year, I sugeest you take a drive to HFS and stand in line for six hours to get this. Or dont because that means I will get through the line faster. Awesome is an understatement.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2014 A- pours an opaque deep cola brown with a thin head of medium tan head. Good lacing. S- strong bourbon nose coupled with vanilla, molasses, burnt sugar and marshmallows creme. Some graham crackers, roasted malts. Charcoal and earth. Hoppy in the back end. M- full oily palate with a medium smooth body. Good carbonation. T- starts with metallic vanilla and bitter dark chocolate. Roasted caramel and coconut, molasses, espresso, chocolate covered cherries in the middle. Dry earth and vegetal malts. Some hop notes follow, with grass and mild soap. Ending is alcohol and bitter chocolate that lasts. Solid.

A wonderful imperial stout.

Strong rich bourbon nose.
Black pour with thin bright brown head
Soft light body, vanilla, bourbon, roasted malts
semisweet soft finish.

500ml bottle In a tulip. Pours black with a lacy, tan head. Aroma or roasted malts, bourbon and oak and vanilla, coffee and dark chocolate, and some dough. Flavor the same with a lot of dark malts and good bourbon. Thick. A great beer.
Deep brown almost black. Thin tan head, flavor and smell of oak, bourbon and malt. Light char from barrel, needs a few months of aging

pours black with a nice crema head, good retention and lacing. burnt hazelnuts, dark woodsy notes, dark fruitiness - bit of raisins, bit of maple and perfume, some sweetness, pinch of bourbon vanilla, bold resin and roasted acidity. moderate to low carbonation, medium to full body - oily, yet not sticky, slightly boozy, assertive peppery-resinous finish. very nice ris - did prefer double barrel tho.

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2013 500 ml bottle shared by a dude at the SIde Project release bottle share- thanks again, Jeff! Pours a deep brown color with a minimal head. Pretty warm in both the aroma and flavor, with a lot of bourbon, molasses, oak, dark chocolate, caramel, roast, and brown sugar. Medium-full bodied, with moderate carbonation and a boozy, warm, coating mouthfeel. Nice imperial stout. Far more aggressive than other HF offerings. Re-Rate: 2011 and 2013 side-by-side. 2011 is better, and for the reasons I stated above: really distinct, rich barrel treatment, and one that doesnt seem to have fallen off with age.

Pour is black with a deep brown head that leaves nice lacing patterns. At first I could only smell some heavy alcohol notes, much akin to smelling rubbing alcohol, but as the glass progressed I could pick up some nice woody, bourbony, vanilla notes. Taste is sweet but not too much with nice coffee, chocolate and caramel flavors. Mouthfeel is creamy, soft and almost oily. Great one for sure! Of course the double barrel treatment was a notch over this one, though. (stating the obvious)

Bottle 500ml.
Pours black with low brown head. Some lacing. Aroma is of roasted malt, chocolate, licorice, alcohol, sugar, wood, oak, vanilla, raisins. Taste is of alcohol, roasted malt, pepper, chocolate, molasses. Palate: Full bodied. "Dry" woody feeling. Overall: Pretty good. Complex. Enjoyable.

This beer pours pitch black with a medium khaki head that diminishes gradually. Partial rings of lacing on the glass. Boozy aroma with roasted malt and chocolate notes. Full-bodied with flavors of chocolate malt, roasted coconut and subtle bourbon. The finish is sweet and boozy with a cocoa and malt aftertaste. Good beer all around.

Opaque black, thin mocha lacing. Wonderful blend of mild bourbon, sweet chocolate, brown sugar, vanilla, oak, espresso, dark fruits, and a hint of smoke. Pleasantly bittersweet, a smidgen of stickiness, and full-bodied. Long finish that showcases the well-masked booziness. Exquisitely well-balanced overall.

im guessing Hill Farmstead went to ancestry.com ... ... pours a deep purple black suit .. . mild foam .. . rich tar and charcoal leakings .. . wish i had gotten more of this, quality brew .. . . i have never understood the Jaquististy Method..

Rating #800! B2 shared at Freetail. Pitch black, minimal brown head and lace. Smooth chocolate, bourbon, silky roasted malt aroma. Pungent, nice. Boozy on the palate when cold, warms up to a nicely balanced RIS with barrels and all other flavors in check. Toffee sweetness midway through, baker's chocolate finishes things out. Viscous body is delightful. Nice stuff, yet similar to the b1 this is not mind blowing.
Freetail mega release. Pours black with creamy beautiful brown head. Aroma is thin smooth malt chocolate good leather. Taste is smooth small greatness interesting chocolate.

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2013 500ml bottle (2011 bottle 721 of 864). THANK YOU SCOTT!!!! Pours a thick jet black color with no head. Aroma of strong bourbon, oak, caramel, vanilla, and chocolate. Nose is definitely boozy. Taste is so smooth. Man this is delicious! Coffee, chocolate fudge brownies, oak, bourbon, and vanilla. This beer is awesome!

Bottle from International trade; dark brown with thin tan head, quite big bourbon aroma, luckily the bourbon doesnt come through in taste quite mellow, rich chocolate taste a hint of caramel and vanilla glorious stuff.

Bottle 50 cl. Vintage 2011. Bottle # 549/864. Listed as 10,0% ABV. Pours a thick, opaque black with a very delicate, creamy light brown head. Thick, sweet and smooth Bourbon aroma atop subdued roast. Some heat in the nose already. Rich, sweet roastiness, a little licorice, vanilla and spicy oak. Warming alcohol finish. Totally balanced and easy going. Delish! 040713

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2013 Bottle (500 ml). Amazing thanks to the guy who served me a generous pour of this beer at Hill Farmstead 3rd anniversary bottle share. Pitch black with a small than head and little lacing. Aroma is amazingly complex and rich with toffee, fudge, molasses, red fruits, vanilla, slight to moderate bourbon notes (not overpowering, well-done!)... wow! Taste is moderately sweet and as rich as aroma. Theres a lot of fudge, caramel and red fruits here with just the right amount of bourbon, wood and vanilla. Slight notes of anise too. Full body. Smooth mouthfeel, oily and velvety. Low to moderate carbonation. So rich and decadent. Almost perfect balance. The barrel treatment is subtle, but so well executed. Wow! 

EDIT: I tried it again just after the 2013 release - side by side with Double Barrel Damon - and it was still really good. It was less complex than the bottle I had in May though and a little too hot, especially compared to Double Barrel Damon. I would wait a couple of months before cracking another bottle. 4-8-8-4-17 = 4.1

Pours a pitch black with no head and no lacing. Aroma of bourbon, chocolate, light coffee. Taste is very rich and decadent. Some chocolate, vanilla, oak, caramel. Full body and low carb. Wow... Really enjoyed this one. Really looking foward to the upcomming variants of this one.

Bottle @ THE Stouts Tasting Pt II. Cheers to Leighton for sourcing this. The pours deep brown with a tiny tan head. Quite sweet on the nose. Loads of creme brulee. Singed brown sugar. Woody vanilla and robust dark chocolate. The taste is similarly sweet. Vanilla cake icing. Hersheys chocolate syrup. Just enough charred grain to keep things in check. Nice cocoa accents on the finish. Smooth, not boozy. Rich, but in control. Overall, pretty excellent work. One of the beers of the night.

Bottle consumed at THE stouts tasting part 2, thanks to Leighton. It pours pretty much black with a small dark tan head. The nose is rich-roasted malt, coffee, toasted coconut, cocoa, and vanilla. The taste is roasted malt, ash, toffee, brown sugar, toast, cocoa powder, chocolate, earth, bourbon, coffee and fudge with a warming finish. Full body, moderate carbonation and sticky mouth-feel. A pretty tasty bourbon barrel-aged imperial stout, but Ive had better (so to speak).

19th March 2013Stouts and Porters II. Thanks to my Hill Farmstead pusher - Leighton for this one. Opaque dark brown - black beer, little tan head, short lived. Smooth palate, a little dry. Mild fine carbonation. Creamy dark malt and a touches of aniseed and vanilla oak. Nice dark chocolate and  mellow bourbon. Softish dry finish.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2013 Bottle shared at Bruces, London during The Stouts Tasting, Pt. II. Pours clearish, dark brown with a small, brown head. Some torched wood in the nose, chocolates malts, hints of booze. Medium to big sweet flavor, lots of bittersweet baking cocoa, torched wood, some booze, dark fruits, bits of. Earth. Medium to full bodied with fine carbonation. Warming finish, more bitter cocoa, ripe dark fruits, raisins, dark cherries, some chocolate cake. Yeah, its good. Damn deep.

Pitch Black soapy pour with no head.  Nose of roasted malt, vanilla, and booze.  Nose is very well balanced.  Taste follows the nose with a little coffee bite and a trace of soy sauce.  Well done all around.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pour a dark brown-black, with mocha lacing. Aroma is decadent fudge, almonds, dates and prunes. Not your usual bourbon barrel imperial stout as it isnt overly bourbony and leans more towards dark fruits and conforting alcohol heat. Not very roasted and coffee either. some dark chocolate and a slight roastiness. Very subtle and refine. Oily mouthfeel and low carbonation.

Pours a rich thick black color with a finger of mocha foam. Aromas are dark sweet and inviting. Big bourbon, vanilla and roasted chocolate. The palate is complex yet smooth and easy to drink... deep cocoa, molasses, fudge and a touch of bittersweet baker chocolate as the flavors draw out into a long lingering finish. So Yummy ! 
*shared with wife after winning this bottle in a raffle at the Harvest Fest 12
Bottle. Black colour with a tan head. Aroma is vanilla, oak, coffee, roasted malt, alcohol. flavour is vanilla, oak, chocolate, roasted malt, caramel, coffee, alcohol. Full body. Very nice beer.

Pour from a bottle thanks to Kan! Pitch black color with a thin tan head. Aromas of coffee, cocoa, anise, and dark fruit. Velvety smooth on you palate. Flavors of bourbon, oak, vanilla, and dark chocolate.  Long finish.

Bottle 500ml. [ Vintage 2011 ]. [ Bottle # 551/864 ]. Clear dark black brown colour with a small, frothy - fizzy, fair lacing, mostly to fully diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, chocolate, berries, wood, alcohol - bourbon. Flavour is heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, bourbox, dried fruit - berry, chocolate. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft, finish feel is moderate alcoholic - bourbon. Very nice ;D [20121109]

Bottle courtesy of Frank, with James, Bill, Alan, and Vinny. Pours a pitch black color with a little head. Aroma is slight cinnamon with roasted chocolates. Taste brings out the cinnamon, some minor chocolate notes, but is very thin. Finishes very quick.

Bottle from the big dad Frank shared with some other daddy-os after the black Friday event. Black oil pour with very small brownish head and lacing. Aromas and taste of peat, mollases, coffee bean, vanilla, wood, nuts, cracker jack, oak, licorice, and sugary chocolate. Medium bodied stout tha finishes a little bitter. Not as much bourbon present as I would have liked in this Impy. Still very nice but I prefer the hoppy beers from HF.

Bottle at franks courtesy of frank with Dallas, Vinny, Alan, bill and frank. Pours a deep black body with thin brown lacing. ArOma is bourbon, rich chocolate and light oak. Mouthfeel is medium to thin with notes of chocolate syrup, cocoa, vanilla, oak, bourbon and wood.

Deep black body, thin tan head, spotty lacing. Rich with dark chocolate, roasted malts, bourbon, vanilla, caramel and oak.  Medium to full bodied, smooth, gentle carbonation, lingering warming finish, light bitterness.

Bottle. The pours is quite oily, its almost black in color and topped by a small, light tan head. Its lightly alcoholic on the nose, with coffee, dark chocolate, some soy sauce and licorice. The aroma suggest quite a lot of sweetness, and thats what you get. As well as licorice and soy sauce hints, as well as dark chocolate and coffee. Quite one tracked, but still complex and pleasant. Full body, warming and soft on the palate. Lasting finish with roasted malts, coffee and some warming alcohol. Wonderful. 121109

Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Almost black with a small dark brown head. Aroma is sweet, roasted malt, heavy chocolate, vanilla and bourbon. Flavor is very sweet and moderate bitter. Sweet finish with warming alcohol. 091112

Bottle 500ml @ fonefan
Pours black with a tan head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, chocolate, alcohol, caramel, vanilla and oak. Taste is heavy sweet and light to medium bitter with a long chocolate, vanilla and oak finish. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Bottle @ FOneFan. Black with tiny dark brown head. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, little liquorice, bourbon and vanilla. Flavour is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, bourbon, vanilla, liquorice, warming, medium sweet with notes of alcohol.
Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Nice head with good duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are roast malt, bourbon, vanilla, fruits, coffee, chocolate and hops. Quite powerful.

Poured from 500ml bottle from Steve Kim, the Beer Pimp.  Poured on 10/8/12, International Stout Day.  Pours dark brown, nearly black with tan head.  Aroma is brownies, some stale coffee and dried fruit.  Taste follows very closely from the nose.  The bourbon is very subdued with a lot of chocolate and roasty notes.

Bottle generously shared by Colin.  Dark brown/black pour with a tan head and a nice sheen.  Big chocolate and caramel aromas.  The body is just a little on the thin side, but still has a nice mouthfeel.  Fantastic chocolate, caramel, fudge, and smooth roasted malt notes.  A very nice imperial stout.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2014 pour is pitch black with a dark brown head and some large bubbles in the middle. Nose has a fair amount of wood and some sweet bourbon notes. Chocolate cake is rich with a faint ashy, roast coffee bean note.  The taste is very big, a bit sweet but not sugary with notes of vanilla and chocolate, the wood isnt as strong but the bourbon seems to add a very nice balance and some heat in the finish. The body is thick, soft, and smooth. Semi dry finish that lingers for a bit as more rich chocolate continues to stay on the palate.*******Had multiple times since first time, overly sweet and a bit singular.  First bottle must have been lightning in a bottle, not nearly as good and had both batches multiple times.  Rating to reflect.

Courtesy of markwise. It pours with a mahogany body that supports a tan head of foam. The aroma offers up dusty dark roasted malts, brownies, black licorice and then mild oak and booze notes at the end of the draw. The taste runs quickly into chocolate, dark roasted malts and black licorice. To midway it begins to pick up mild boozy barrel notes and then into the finish the chocolate brownie notes and booze linger into the after taste. Yummers.

500 ml bottle generously shared by scottfrie.  Thanks Scott.  Pours a dark black with just a bit of light coming through at the edges.  A small tan head settles to a ring and leaves some light lacing on the glass.  The aroma is lots of bourbon, vanilla, oak, quite a bit of chocolate, and some light coffee.  The taste is sweet with quite a bit of bourbon, some vanilla, a bit of oak, and lots of rich chocolate.  There is also a light nuttiness.  The finish is sweet with more rich chocolate and some oak and a light alcohol presence.  Medium body.  Low carbonation.  Solid beer.  Really rich.

Bottle. Pours solid black with virtually no head and no carbonation. Aroma of darkly roasted malts, rich chocolate, balanced bourbon, cherry, vanilla, coffee. Flavour is the same, very rich. The bourbon is more prominent than on the nose. The other flavours seem dampened in comparison - may benefit from warming up a little more. Liqueur-like warming sensation. Never thought Id say this but I feel it would benefit from a light carbonation. Very smooth. Most certainly a slow sipper. Very good, but I do feel a little disappointed - maybe my expectations for this brewer were slightly inflated? Hope not!

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2012 500mL bottle, sent from Glouglouburp (thanks a lot, Dany!), pours like engine oil, a pitch black with zero head, just a few bubbles. Decadent aroma of chocolate fudge and bourbon barrels upfront with some vanilla and subtle espresso beans further back. Flavour is rich and decadent, with more of the chocolate fudge, more dominant bourbon barrels than the nose suggests, and a prominent alcohol burn. Balanced beautifully between these three main qualities, leaving a chocolately alcohol burn on the finish. Almost zero carbonation - usually I wouldnt complain about this, but in this case (as Matts_Property says), I think slightly higher carbonation would benefit the mouthfeel. Silky smooth and thick body. Decadent and quite easy to drink for the style despite being a bourbon booze bomb. Delicious stuff.

Appearance: Pours a dark brown with some bubbly tan edges.

Aroma:  Dark chocolate, cake batter, whiskey.

Taste:  Smokey malt, dark chocolate, light burnt roast dark fruit.

Mouthfeel: Full bodied soft carbonation.

Overall: A very balanced, cohesive bourbon barrel aged impy. While I love the big monster, messy bourbon barrel aged stouts, this one was enjoyable, with more than just in your face bourbon, chocolate and caramel.

Bottle courtesy of Matt.  Cheers, sir!  Pours a nice obsidian color with a tan head.  Nose is roasted malt, chocolate, cocoa, booze, whiskey, vanilla, some light earth, and a hint of love.  Flavor is similar with chocolate, cocoa, vanilla, booze, whiskey, and some earth.  A nice blend of barrel, wood, and chocolatey/ roasty imperial stout.  Medium to full in body and a very nice sipper overall.

500 ml bottle received in trade. Thank you Glouglouburp! Pours black with a small dark mocha head that quickly dissipates without leaving much trace. Smell is sweet and tiny spicy with roasted malts, black pepper, dark bread, roasted coconut, bilberries, dark chocolate, brown sugar, charred wood, dark roast coffee, cinnamon, moist soil, burnt caramel, lemon balm and hints of pine. Taste is sweet, tiny bitter and very malty with roasted malts, charred wood, chipotle peppers, sweet dark bread, black peppercorns, moist soil, very dark quality chocolate, vanilla fudge, roasted coconut, caramel, toffee, bourbon, dill, orange zest, resin, alcohol and hints of burnt sugar. Mouthfeel is smooth, round, tiny sticky sweet, tiny oily bitter and full bodied. Finish is sweet and slightly bitter with roasted malts, dark chocolate, dark roast coffee, vanilla fudge, burnt caramel and hints of charred coconut, resinous wood, dill and bourbon. Extremely nice! As expected I guess...

(Bottle) Pours black with small brown head. The aroma holds black currant, blueberries, cocoa, dark chocolate ice cream, asphalt, touch of smoked meat, roasted marshmallows, wood and a whisper of cinnamon and chilly. Balanced, fancy and structured nose. A tiny dash of hops. The flavour is light to medium sweet, medium bitter and light acidic with citric/earthy hops, wood, vanilla/cinnamon/chilly spices, deep roasted/light dark caramelly malt. The mouthfeel is round, smooth, light tart and tiny sticky with a light carbonation. Well structured flavour as well. Long balanced/luxurious roasted and bitter hops. Near full bodied.

Bottle at Mumsig Miniprovning, Göteborg. Pitch black beer, small beige head. Malty chocolate aroma, cocoa, vanilla, licorice, blueberries, roasted, tar notes, berries, woody, some alcohol, roasted, bourbon, coffee notes, some figs. Malty chocolate flavor, tar, figs, bitter hops, grass, quite roasted, cocoa, vinous, raisins, woody, bourbon, vanilla notes, chilli notes, salty, some pepper. Wonderful beer in all aspects. Perfect body and with balance in all flavors. Chocolate finish, cocoa, fruity notes, bitter hops and some bourbon. Lovely!

Bottle @ MMP. Pours pitch black with a shortlived brown head. Aroma is roasted malty sweet fruity berry tary soy. Flavor is sweet roasted acidy peppery bitter malty fruity velvety full bodied coffee chocolate. Finishes sweet longlived bitter roasted.

Pours jet black with a red hue. Aroma of bourbon, chocolate malts and slight hops. Taste follows, so chewy, chocolatey and amazing. Lives up to the hype and then some. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

In short: A superior BA Imperial Stout that doesnt overdo anything.  Classy beer
How: Tap at brewery + bottle aged about 4 months (this rating)
The look: Black body topped by a medium tan head with good retention
In long: Nose is moderately bourbon with some nice fresh bakery black chocolate and freshly roasted coffee beans.  Not sure what his trick is, I can understand that HF makes IPAs that proposes a superb freshness in the aroma, but now even his BA Imperial Stout are a breath a freshness.  Taste is more of the same, a perfect execution of simplicity.  Fresh bakery chocolate, some bourbon but not too much, a good amount a superior quality coffee beans, mild notes of vanilla, grilled marshmallows, medium oak barrels presence, rich chocolate fudge, medium roast level, still enough hops presence to provide some kind of balance.  No alcohol presence and a sweetness sensation lower than expected.  This is once again too easy to drink for a high gravity beer, a recurrent theme with Hill Farmstead beers.  Basically it has almost all the basic elements of the style minus the fruity flavors, but what makes this one stand out is not the intensity or a specific flavor element, what makes this one stand out is how perfectly levelled each flavor element is and how drinkable it is for the style.  If youre looking for a brutal boozy sugar bomb (very popular on ratebeer) then this is not the beer for you, but if youre looking for class and refinement, this is the BA Imperial Stout you want.  I really loved that beer, even the 89.5% part that is not alcohol.

Thanks for sharing, Joe!  Pours black in color with a small tan head.  Very roasty with plenty of dark chocolate.  A mild vanilla note, some bourbon, and a bit of oak.  The flavor is heavy on the roast and is mildly bitter.  Some bourbon, oak, and vanilla.  Dark chocolate, a bit of ash, maybe some dark fruit notes as well.  Good, but not amazing.

2011 bottle 684 of 864...Pours pitch black with ruby hues and a medium dark mocha head...thick and oily looking.  Aroma is bold and roasty with dark fruit...fig...and a touch of dark chocolate and bourbon...mild booziness.  Flavor has chocolate, tobacco, coffee, ash, dark fruit, and just a touch of bourbon.  Mouthfeel is full and creamy with a very warming roasty bourbon finish.

Bottle shared much thanks to Scott! Pours out prettymuch black with a small to moderate tan head. Aroma is of chocolate, smooth, light bourbon, oak, light coffee. Taste is very complex with a smooth mouthfeel. Notes of chocolate, light wood, bourbon, caramel, sweet dried fruits, light earth and a smooth, bourbon note on the finish. Awesome stuff.

From notes.  Poured from a 500 mL bottle into a tulip.  

Damon has a nearly black color with coffee brown edges.  There is a small mocha tan cap that leaves a few wisps of lacing.

The aroma is sweet bourbon, creamy chocolate, a bit of dark roast coffee, and a full roasted malt presence.  

The flavor starts with a light and smooth bourbon flavor.  Then there is creamy dark chocolate, full roasted malt, some milk chocolate, caramel, vanilla, and oak, with a bit more bourbon on the finish.  

It has a very nice full body, rich, creamy carbonation, and a little bit sticky mouthfeel.  Damon is definitely rich and creamy.

Overall Damon does a great job of packing a smooth, tasty bourbon barrel stout into a nice, full-bodied package.
Sampled at Small Peen.  Black!  Small ring.  Just had a DL de Muerte so my taste buds are not ideal.  I smell wood and bourbon.  So much ash and bitterness.  Big bitterness, too.

At Tria Fermentation.  Poured a deep plum black with red hues and no head (look reminded me of a big bold cabernet).  Aroma was big on chocolate and plum with notes of bourbon and roasted malt.  Flavor begins with roasted malt and semi sweet dark chocolate followed by hints of vanilla and bourbon before a velvety balanced finish.

Draft at tria... Black pour with no head... looks oily and viscous. Taste is oily imperial stout. Roasted malts, light chocolate, dark fruits. Alcohol is a little noticable. Overall a sweet bitter taste. Oily body but not sticky. Overall: I didnt enjoy this beer that much

50cl, Vintage 2011, Bottle 99/864, at 10%Vol, new exclusive American brew, thx to AdamJackson!, very complex Stout, roasted/sweet and slightly alcoholic/fruity, not too heavy, very balanced, cloudy, small head, top class!

Bottle from hbmason...thanks Tim! - Pours big and black, with a thin tan ring of head. A little hot and a bit of hoppiness on the nose--that was unexpected--with bourbon and a lot of sweet dark malt. Vanilla really shows itself in the taste, smooth with lots of dark roasty malt, dark chocolate, and an espresso finish. Very little carbonation--thick, smooth, and slick. Very good stuff.

2011 black waxed 500 mL bottle. 578/864. Thanks to Ashley and Tucker for hooking us up with this gem.

Pours a viscous dark chocolate with a large, frothy yellowish light tan head. Excellent retention, fading to a collar and spotty film. Thin streaks and dots of lacing.

Smooth, subtle aroma of roast malt, black licorice, coffee, vanilla, and bourbon in the finish.

Flavor is sweet and smooth with a subtle blend of black licorice, bourbon, mild oak and vanilla. Incredibly balance and blend between the base stout and the barrel and well restrained alcohol presence. 

Medium thick, smooth body with light carbonation and an everlasting chewy, licrorice finish.

Wow, Genealogy was amazing and Damon is as well. Both are distinct from most other stouts in their malt profile and while HF has not released many stouts yet, they are going to destroy this style just as they have IPAs. Boom!

Bottle shared at perfect temp by chpueblo22, thanks Tom! Damon pours a deep black with a light brown, mocha head. The nose is rich with coffee, dark roasted malts and an earthy deep rooted oak. Taste is roasty coffee, chocolate, cocoa nibs, and more heavy chocolate. Dry roasted finish with low carbonation and a medium to full mouthfeel. Also got slight notes of anise and alcohol, but they very much complimented the beer. Cant wait to have this beer again if possible.

Bottle shared by Madvike while waiting for GTMW tickets, wow, thanks for sharing this one Matt.  Pours black with a nice thick brown head and lacing through out the tasting glass.  Aroma is full of bourbon, oak and chocolate but one doesnt overpower the other.  The flavor is very rich with some dark fruits coming through with the bourbon.  Extremely rich and smooth, a delicious beer.

Bottle shared in line for GTMW tickets (Madison, WI). Pours a rich blackish pour, with deep and dark, near opaque with ruby brown edges. A frothy tannish head dies to a ring, laces small. Aromas are rich, deep and dark with toffee, roast, and biscuits. Firm barrel elements preach oak, gentle spirit, vanilla. A touch of dark fruit grows, with some gentle anise, cocoa, and toffee. Nice and full. Initial is full bodied offering lively dryness and tons of bakers cocoa up front. Dry and roasty, touches of toast, firm toffee and caramel sweetness, with touches of dark. Rich oak and barrel elements show some life into the middle, offering some good flavors. Backend is mellow thick sweetness, some good oak, swee sticky cocoa, caramel, and biscuits. Awesome.

Bottle, pours a nice dark black, tan head, very viscous and lots chocolate in the aroma, the bourbon is a little subdued and overall this is quite smooth and really quite enjoyable. as this one warmed it got better and better. Very nice offering

Funny coincidence on the timing of the HF tasting.  If only wed had some nice cheese to go with it.  Pours out black and fairly viscous with brown edges. Little carb, just a few bubbles on the edges. Nose is great, chocolate, bourbon, brown sugar, and a hint of toasted marshmallow. Taste is subtle and smooth, malted milk chocolate, bourbon, caramel, and vanilla. The longer I sip it, the better it gets.  Very well balanced beer.  However, it is light bodied with low carbonation.  Otherwise, super impressive.  If it had the awesome feel of Everett itd be near perfect.  As it is, its only superb.

Opened by Baron for our Hill Farmstead tasting, thanks man!  Pours a deep black with some brown hues around the edges. Not much head on the pour, some soapy bubbles on the surface.  Nose is beautiful, rich chocolate, sweet bourbon, brown sugar, some coffee, and toasted marshmallow. Taste is a little muted but smooth, milk chocolate, bourbon, oak, brown sugar, caramel, and a tiny amount of vanilla, really well balanced. The only downfall of the beer, it is really light bodied. Carbonation is low, but has a nice finish. Really impressive, if this was a little thicker, this would be top tier. Flavor and nose are exceptional.

Bottle 669 of 864 +++Sampled from a 16 oz brown bottle this beer poured a black color with a trace beige head that left a touch of lacing. The aroma was coconut, bourbon, vanilla, anise, port wine, noticeable alcohol and a bit of band-aid. The flavor was wood, port wine, vanilla, anise, whiskey, coconut, band-aid and maple syrup. The finish was long and very boozy with coconut and whiskey lingering. Thick and full bodied though undercarbonated. Interesting.

500ml bottle thanks to dsgolovin on BA.  Black in color with a half finger off well-formed brown head.  Rich complex aroma with big chocolate, muted coffee, toasted coconut, and vanilla.  The flavor has a restrained sweetness as well as a mild bitterness, with dark chocolate, sugary roasty malt, espresso, oak, vanilla, and bourbon.  Medium-bodied - the lightness makes it more drinkable - but not thin with average carbonation and a touch of hotness/booze.  Great beer once again from Hill Farmstead.

Really solid BA beer. 
Lots of chocolate, bourbon, oak, vanilla, and coconut. 
Taste is a bit of a let down for the first 15-20 minutes and then WHAM it gets serious. 
Long lasting flavor and quite coating. Coconut flavors really pick up in this. 
Quite impressed by this

Bottle Pours dark brown (nearly black) with a small, creamy, lightly tanned head. The nose is a dark swirl of blackstrap molasses, leather, dark chocolate, fudge and a nice vanilla nuance. Full-bodied and creamy with modest carbonation. The flavor is sweet chocolate, warming whiskey and a pinch of bitter cocoa. Hearty, warming bittersweet finish. Big-time thanks go out to newcigarz for sharing this rarity!

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2012 Bigtime thanks to my main man adamjackson for this tight beer. Notes of clean, rich, potent,  dark chocolate, cream, vanilla,  grham crackers and bigtime lucious bourbon.  Pleasant warming alcohol.   Creamy chocolate cocoa and bourbon.   Reminicient of awesome regular bcs releases.   Great balance, body, attenuation.    Seems best now.  Awesome.
Bottle #467/864. Pours black with a hint of a tan head. Aromas of bourbon, chocolate and vanilla. Taste brings more of the same, but with an underlying vinous note. Very enjoyable.

Bottle, shared with Dave (ucusty).  This beer is decadent and so fucking drinkable.  Bourbon works very well, one of the best bourbon aged beers Ive had.  I wasnt surprised I liked it so much when I found out that the barrels used are from Blantons Bourbon.  But really this beer could be aged in aristocrat bourbon and it would probably still be better than 90% of the other imperial stouts out there.   In short: Yum.  Thanks dude.

50cl bottle pours an oily, opaque black with zero head.  Nose is smokey, nail polish remover, waxy, maple candy, sweet, bourbon.  Flavor is sweet, chocolate liqueur, strong maple undertones, some cola, caramel, vanilla beans, mint, watered down bourbon.  Full bodied, oily finish.

Thanks to Sam for sharing this one!   Viscous dark pour with a chestnut brown colored head.   Aroma is vanilla, creamy oak, and bourbon.  Oily fudge with blasts of bourbon and vanilla.   Awesome stuff

Pours dark unclear black with a small dark beige head, lighter carbonation. The aroma bring a nutty barrel note, pleasant and light with delicious brown sugar and sweet light vanilla notes. The flavor brings a lot of delicious sweet booze notes from the barrel that spice up the lips and tongue in a good way.

Bottle shared by Scott. Poured a dark brown/blackish with a smaller brown foamy head. Aroma of citrusy-orange, barrell, bourbon, vanilla syrup, dark choclate and some grassy hops. Full bodied that is smooth with light carbonation and just enough warmth to let you know that this is strong and special. Flavor of chocolate pudding, bourbon, oak, vanilla, burnt toast, dry dark chocolate. Awesome beer.

500ml bottle, 2011 vintage, #490/864.  Nearly pitch black, the dense body supports a thin, swirly, light brown film, leaving behind a soapy, glass-staining wash that slowly rejoins the body.  Based in lush, über-rich, bittersweet dark chocolate, the velvety-smooth malts suggest of caramel and toasted brownie.  An overlying wash of smooth, wood-kissed bourbon, spicy vanilla bean, and mild smoke wrap everything up beautifully.  Flavors follow right in line.  Wave after wave of rich dark chocolate and lightly scorched caramel are quite sweet, touching also on dulce de leche, soft vanilla, fading green hops, and lush, lush bourbon.  Super smooth and expertly balanced.  The palate is nearly full, yet light enough to show some life.  Theres a (welcomed) lightly papery texture that keeps things from getting overly syrupy, yet the sugars do a good job of covering up the alcoholic heat.  Damn fine beer.  Much better than the Twilight of the Idols porter I had last night, and one of the better imperial stouts Ive had in recent memory.
On draft pour.  Pitch black with a light beige head.  Chocolate, and bourbon on the nose.  Taste is more of the same.  Well balanced.

dark murky brown, large bubbled tan ring gravity head. Hot nose is cake and chocolate with considerable bourbon, masking a bit. Beautiful body, decadent thick and oily, fudge with bourbon hints sliding across front with considerable cake and ash through mod-finish, heat adding complexity before faintest paper, chocolate reemerging. Rich, decadent, complex. As close to bells best stouts as Ive seen.

Nearly black pour, wispy brown head. Aroma is chocolate fudge, vanilla, toffee, a light spicy hop note. Flavor is rich and decadent! Fudge, vanilla, perfect roast, bourbon, vanilla. Restrained yet luxurious.

500ml bottle shared by ygtbsm94: Pours an opaque black with dark mahogany edges and a stringy-lacing beige head.  Has a sweet dark caramel and chocolate nose with some vanilla and bourbon oak character.  Starts with good fullness and chewy sweet dark maltiness with a dry roasty dark coffee and bourbon oak complexity before a slightly warming dark chocolate finish.  An enjoyable bourbon imperial stout.

50cl bottle, thanks ygtbsm94.  Minimal beige head atop brown-black body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, Bourbon, oak, some milk chocolate.  Taste is moderately sweet, Bourbon, milk chocolate, some alcohol.  Smooth ,sticky medium-full body.

Bottle shared by ygtbsm94.  Pours opaque with a small, fizzy tan head, short retention with light lacing.  Aroma is bourbon, roast and chocolate malt with vanilla and oak, licorice and light smoke.  Flavor is malt dominant with bourbon, oak and vanilla, light hops and bitterness, alcohol and a sweet finish.  Full body, medium warmth and carbonation.

22oz bottle. Nice to see that Damon (dog) is considered apart of the family and gets a beer named after him! Poured a dark black color with a small sized tan head. Aromas of wood, some earth, bourbon, roast, and chocolate. Tastes of vanilla, bourbon, roast, dark fruits, caramel, and chocolate. Softer and silky body with the alcohol hidden. Nothing really stood out in your face, but that being said, it all blended together nicely.

Pours a thick jet black with a small dark caramel head.  A looker.  Nose is roasted malt, some charred oak, touches of dark anise and coffee beans. Layers of rich fresh coffee beans, anise, dark fruits, super dark gooey chocolate cake.  Finish is a brilliant collage of bakers chocolate, lightly roasted malts, and a barrel kiss that is totally unique in its own right.  As with Birth of Tragedy its almost blackberry-like at times.  Palate medium.  A sort of empty spot on the palate, a bit thin at times, otherwise excellent.

500mL thanks to oteyj. Rating #3500. Pours pretty much ink with a thicker reddish mocha head. Nice retention with wispy, sticky dark lace. Nose is pretty sweet, cinnamon, spicy Mexican chocolate, sharp vanilla bean and dark chocolate ice cream. Oh yeah. Incredible crystalized sugared chocolate nose. So much powerful vanilla dark chocolate brownie mix. Taste is silky, thicker, bitter, sugary dark chocolate. Oh man this is good. Excellent bitter dark chocolate palate. Thick Godiva liquor palate is of the charts. Delicious. 8/4/8/5/17=4.2

Got this about a week ago and left it in the mini fridge at 50f to settle.Pours a black color with a medium frothy dark brown head that slowly dissipates. Color has a crimson hue on the edges but cant see through the black liquid. Smell is chocolate caramel with a clean roast. Plenty of oak vanilla and spirit chacteristics. After it sits the edge of spirit gives way to vanilla and chocolate. Taste is rich dark caramel with a smooth roastiness and vanilla. Clean spirit characteristics without the alcohol fume. There is a sweetness but a bite of bitterness, semi sweet dry finish.  mouth feel is silky smooth, full body with mild carbonation. Creamy coating every tastebud. overall this may be, nay, is my favorite bb stout ever.

Opaque black with a medium sized, tan head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of roasted malts, lighter vanilla, bourbon, charred wood, and light alcohol. Taste was more roasty, lighter wood, bourbon, dark fruits, and alcohol in the finish.

Huge thanks to yourefragile for sharing this bottle. No Hill Farmstead tulip; damn my early packing. Bottle number 578/864.

Pours near black with a good tan head and some spotty, streaky lacing on the way down. The nose carries a great dose of bourbon and chocolate with some very mild roast in the background. Flavor has big bourbon and oak with some accompanying vanilla. Medium body with smooth carbonation. Über smooth. Really fantastic. Just a touch of booze for warmth. Fantastic.

Poured into a Portsmouth tulip.  Thick pitch-black body with a thin dark-tan head.  Looks beautiful.  Leaves some nice lacing on the glass.  The nose is packed with cocoa, bourbon, wood and vanilla.  Smells amazing.  Roasty with a touch of booze.  On the tongue its sweet bourbon and vanilla up front, but then finishes with a wave of dark chocolate and some dry, earthy, dark malt bitterness on the tail end.  The 10% abv is noticeable, but doesnt get in the way of taste or enjoyment.  Very drinkable for a barrel aged imperial stout.  The body is smooth and creamy with light carbonation.  Overall, this is phenomenal, but Hill Farmstead never disappoints.  Damon is drinking excellently now, but Im sure it will hold up or even get better in the years to come.  Beautiful.

Bottle from the recent release.  Poured oily black with brown shallow head.  Aroma was raw bourbon, alcohol, vanilla, and ash.  Taste was amazing with subtle to strong flavor notes of vanilla, chocolate, wood, coffee, with a light roasty sweetness and a dry flavorful finish.  Really a tasty treat that I think will improve with age.
Bottle from release! Wow!!! So much vanilla, oak, bourbon, that tasty roasty alcohol hot finish. Fucking shit

Huge thanks to oteyj for bringing this back from the release!!! Inky black pour with a bubbly brown head. The nose is incredibly sweet but oh so luscious, with amazing notes of rich chocolate ganache, black cherry, vanilla bourbon sweetness, rich cream and milk, Belgian truffle, and an awesome but ever so light spiciness that presumably is a sort of imparting of whiskey from the barrel into that sweet chocolate. The flavor brings increased bitter bakers chocolate and cacao, along with gorgeous refined vanilla, oak, and bourbon.
